title: Self-driving cars will cause gridlock in our cities
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Predict
Sign inGet started

Self-driving cars will cause gridlock in our cities

Alan Jones
Mar 25

In order to avoid parking fees, autonomous vehicles (AVs) will slowly cruise around town waiting to pick up their owners.

This is the conclusion of Adam Millard-Ball, transport planner and associate professor of environmental studies at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

At the moment, parking fees persuade drivers to leave their cars outside the city centre and use public transport. But AVs won’t have to park. They’ll be able to slowly and autonomously roam around until they are needed.

Millard-Ball has used game theory to show that AVs will actively collude in order to slow down traffic as, slowly cruising, will cost much less than any parking fee (around 50 cents an hour). When you add to that previous work by Millard-Ball that suggests pedestrians will be happy to walk into the traffic, in the secure knowledge that AVs will stop in order to prevent a collision, gridlock seems inevitable.

Congestion charging in London

Although it is unpopular with commuters, the solution is a congestion charge. This is a charge that drivers have to pay in order to enter the city centre.

This type of scheme has been operating in London, UK, for around 15 years and has improved congestion significantly; it had reduced overall traffic and, consequently, journey times are lower.

In London, there is a flat fee for entering the congestion zone and this operates during daytime on weekdays. Cameras around the zone track cars going in and out and license plate recognition enables the authorities to identify them.

Though the congestion charge, in London, has improved traffic flow, in recent years congestion has been worsening — possibly due to a significant increase in Uber-type cabs. Modern technology, however, could now enforce a more sophisticated scheme, where a variable fee is charged depending on where the car enters the city and how long it is there for.

Congestion fees in cities will discourage driving in the centre and encourage the use of public transport thus reducing the possibility of gridlock.

A more drastic solution would be to ban private cars from city centres all together. Again, this is likely to be unpopular and would require a very good public transport system, which in the age of self-driving cars could be small independent AVs that can be picked up at out of town parking lots.

Resistance

Millard-Ball’s solution is a congestion charge, however, but he sees a problem in its implementation. It’s difficult to persuade people that it is a good idea to charge them for something that had previously been free. He, therefore, thinks that this is something that needs to be acted on soon before AVs become common.

London faced this problem and there were even legal challenges to the imposition of the charge. However, the proponents of the congestion charge prevailed and it is unlikely to go away any time soon.

Sources

The Autonomous Vehicle Parking Problem, Adam Millard-Ball, in Transport Policy.

Would you bully a self-driving car?, Alan Jones, at Medium

London congestion charge: what worked, what didn’t, what next, Nicole Badstuber, in The Conversation

Originally published at technofileblog.blogspot.com.

  • Self Driving Cars
  • Av
  • Cities
  • Future
  • Congestion Pricing

  • Alan Jones

    An ex-university professor and software engineer, I write about AI, programming and technology. Twitter:@MrAlanJones Web:https://alanjones.pythonanywhere.com

  • Predict

    where the future is written
